0: Prepare and process import and export documentation according to customs regulations, laws, or procedures.
Clear goods through customs and to their destinations for clients.
Pay, or arrange for payment of, taxes and duties on shipments.
Calculate duty and tariff payments owed on shipments.
Request or compile necessary import documentation, such as customs invoices, certificates of origin, and cargo-control documents.
Classify goods according to tariff coding system.
Stay abreast of changes in import or export laws or regulations by reading current literature, attending meetings or conferences, or conferring with colleagues.
Sign documents on behalf of clients, using powers of attorney.
Advise customers on import and export restrictions, tariff systems, insurance requirements, quotas, or other customs-related matters.
Post bonds for the products being imported or assist clients in obtaining bonds.
Quote duty and tax rates on goods to be imported, based on federal tariffs and excise taxes.
Arrange for transportation, warehousing, or product distribution of imported or exported products.
Monitor or trace the location of goods.
Confer with officials in various agencies to facilitate clearance of goods through customs and quarantine.
Inform importers and exporters of steps to reduce duties and taxes.
Obtain line releases for frequent shippers of low-risk commodities, high-volume entries, or multiple-container loads.
Provide advice on transportation options, types of carriers, or shipping routes.
Contract with freight forwarders for destination services.
Apply for tariff concessions or for duty drawbacks and other refunds.
Insure cargo against loss, damage, or pilferage.
Prepare papers for shippers to appeal duty charges.
1: Analyze training needs to develop new training programs or modify and improve existing programs.
Evaluate instructor performance and the effectiveness of training programs, providing recommendations for improvement.

Plan, develop, and provide training and staff development programs, using knowledge of the effectiveness of methods such as classroom training, demonstrations, on-the-job training, meetings, conferences, and workshops.
Confer with management and conduct surveys to identify training needs based on projected production processes, changes, and other factors.
Conduct orientation sessions and arrange on-the-job training for new hires.
Train instructors and supervisors in techniques and skills for training and dealing with employees.
Develop and organize training manuals, multimedia visual aids, and other educational materials.
Prepare training budget for department or organization.
Conduct or arrange for ongoing technical training and personal development classes for staff members.
Review and evaluate training and apprenticeship programs for compliance with government standards.
2: Monitor and record food temperatures to ensure food safety.
Cook foodstuffs according to menus, special dietary or nutritional restrictions, or numbers of portions to be served.
Rotate and store food supplies.
Wash pots, pans, dishes, utensils, or other cooking equipment.
Apportion and serve food to facility residents, employees, or patrons.
Clean and inspect galley equipment, kitchen appliances, and work areas to ensure cleanliness and functional operation.
Clean, cut, and cook meat, fish, or poultry.
Direct activities of one or more workers who assist in preparing and serving meals.
Train new employees.
Take inventory of supplies and equipment.
Requisition food supplies, kitchen equipment, and appliances, based on estimates of future needs.
Bake breads, rolls, or other pastries.

0: Conducting customs declarations for import/export shipments to ensure compliance with regulations.
Analyzing and preparing necessary documentation, such as commercial invoices and packing lists.
Verifying the authenticity of goods and identifying any potential customs restrictions or duties.
Negotiating with suppliers, buyers, or other stakeholders to resolve any issues related to customs clearance.
Coordinating with import/export brokers, freight forwarders, or shipping lines to facilitate smooth transportation.
Preparing and submitting export declarations for international shipments, including obtaining necessary permits.
Reviewing and updating client information on the Automated Broker Interface (ABI) system.
Managing and tracking shipment status updates from customs authorities, such as the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP).
Providing guidance to clients on compliance requirements, regulations, and procedures for specific countries or industries.
Responding to client inquiries and resolving any concerns related to customs clearance or shipments.
Maintaining accurate records of imports, exports, and customs data, including reporting to regulatory bodies.
Monitoring market trends and competitor activity to stay up-to-date on changing regulations and trade practices.
Facilitating communication between clients, suppliers, and other stakeholders during the customs clearance process.
Overseeing the preparation and submission of Harmonized System (HS) codes for customs declarations.
Ensuring compliance with anti-money laundering (AML) and know-your-customer (KYC) regulations.
Reviewing and correcting errors or discrepancies in customs documentation to prevent delays or fines.
Providing training and support to clients on how to use customs software, systems, and technologies.
Staying up-to-date on changes to tariffs, quotas, and other trade regulations that may impact client shipments.
description

Customs Brokers facilitate the importation and exportation of goods by handling all aspects of customs clearance. They work closely with clients, suppliers, buyers, and other stakeholders to ensure compliance with regulations, manage paperwork, track shipment status, and provide expert guidance on trade practices and market trends.

These task statements illustrate the diverse range of duties that a Customs Broker performs daily, from preparing documentation to coordinating logistics, and from resolving issues to maintaining accurate records. Their expertise is crucial in ensuring smooth customs clearance for clients across various industries and regions.
1:
Develops training programs to meet the needs of employees, customers, or partners.
Schedules and delivers training sessions, workshops, or online courses.
Evaluates the effectiveness of training programs using various metrics such as participation rates, feedback, and knowledge retention.
Analyzes data from training evaluations to identify trends and areas for improvement.
Conducts needs assessments to determine the training requirements of employees, customers, or partners.
Creates content for training materials such as manuals, guides, and presentations.
Develops and implements training budgets and evaluates ROI (Return on Investment) of training programs.
Collaborates with subject matter experts to create high-quality training content.
Mentors and coaches employees who participate in training programs to ensure they apply what they've learned.
Sources and selects training vendors, tools, or services as needed.
Fosters a culture of continuous learning by encouraging employees to pursue their own professional development.
2: Prepare meals according to recipes and kitchen orders.
Maintain a clean and organized kitchen workspace.
Order ingredients and supplies in advance of meal services.
Supervise food preparation by kitchen staff to ensure quality and safety.
Prepare side dishes and garnishes for meals.
Reheat and re-plate leftover food for serving.
Monitor and adjust cooking temperatures and times as needed.
Clean and sanitize equipment, utensils, and work surfaces.
Maintain inventory of ingredients and supplies.
Assist with food preparation and service during peak periods.
Check expiration dates of ingredients and dispose of spoiled or near-spoiled products.
Prepare specialty dishes for events and functions.
